alert.note: Alert for Roanoke (Virginia) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Advisory issued February 13 at 1:56AM EST by NWS Blacksburg
info.description: .Widespread significant rainfall fell across the region Sunday. Much of the upper Roanoke River basin saw between 2 and 3 inches of rain during the past 24 hours. This has resulted in excessive runoff into area creeks, streams, and rivers causing water levels to rise. Although the rain has stopped, it will take several hours for water levels to reach their peak levels and then recede through the later morning hours. ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 545 AM EST EARLY THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding from earlier heavy rainfall and associated water runoff. * WHERE...Western Roanoke County between the Montgomery County line and Salem, including areas such as Glenvar and Fort Lewis. * WHEN...Until 545 AM EST. * IMPACTS...River or stream flows are elevated. Overflowing poor drainage areas can be expected. In addition, some low-water crossings may become impassable, especially adjacent to any creeks, streams, or rivers. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 150 AM EST, The Roanoke river gage at Glenvar had reached 8.8 ft. at 145 AM EST this morning. Flood stage is 9.0 feet. The river is expected to crest near 9.0 feet between 2 AM and 4 AM EST this morning. Areas adjacent to the river near Glenvar and western Roanoke county may experience minor flooding over the next several hours early this morning. - This includes the following streams and drainages... Roanoke River, Dry Branch and Big Bear Rock Branch. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Western Roanoke County... Glenvar... Fort Lewis... - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Be aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads. In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded roads. Find an alternate route. When it is safe to do so, please send your reports of flooding, including mudslides or flooded roads, to the National Weather Service by calling toll free at 1...8 6 6...2 1 5...4 3 2 4. Reports and pictures can also be shared on the National Weather Service Blacksburg Facebook page and on Twitter.
